Dear Ms. Cheatham:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 7/1/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
One of eight open foster care records reviewed was missing an updated service
plan.
FOM Policy 722 – 06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames
as outlined in the following tables:
Updated Case Plan (USP)- within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.

Three of eight foster care case records reviewed did not contain documentation
that an FTM was held 30 calendar days before the case service plan was due.
Repeat Violation Established
2023 Interim, CAP approved 9/19/23
2022 Renewal, CAP approved 7/13/22
FOM POLICY 722-08D Treatment Plans – Agreement and Signatures
Once completed and approved the caseworker
must obtain signatures from the following
individuals, as applicable:
Caseworker, Supervisor, second line supervisor,
when siblings in care are place apart, parents
who are a member of a participating household.
Youth ages 14 and older. Foster parents, relative
caregivers, and unrelated court -ordered
caregivers. Parents/legal guardians, youth, and
caregivers must check yes or no for the following
when signing the treatment plan: I have
participated in the Development of the Case
service plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
Seven of eight foster care records reviewed did not contain all required PATP
signatures timely or the PATP was missing for the report.
Repeat Violation Established
2023 Interim, CAP approved 7/13/23

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD

There was one substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. Special evaluation 2024C000140SE was initiated on February 14, 2024,
regarding allegation the adoptive son snatched his adoptive mother’s glasses off her
face and caused a minor injury. Law enforcement was involved. The adoptive mother
and the adoptive son have been in a sexual relationship for two years. There are two
other younger foster children placed in the home. The adoptive mother was found in
violation with licensing rules. The evaluation was detailed and well written.
Revocation and central registry were initiated.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with the individual CAP is as follows.
A CAP approved September 19, 2023, was the result of the September 5, 2023,
interim evaluation. During the 2023 review the agency had violations regarding
adoption family evaluation, family team meetings (FTM) and parent agency
treatment plans (PATP). The agency reported successful implementation of the
prior CAP. During the current review the agency showed improvement with the
adoption family evaluation. However, repeat violations were determined regarding
FTMs and PATPs. A new CAP will be developed to address the repeat violations
as the prior CAP was not successful.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator assessment was reviewed and discussed with the director.
The director stated their most consistent barrier continues to be parents visiting
with their children. She stated the social work contacts for parents/children and
parents/workers are the most concerning. She stated the agency has a lot of
parents that are inconsistent with attending parenting time and complying with
their parent agency treatment plans (PATP’s).
The director stated the staff have completed the trainings and implemented the
changes that were identified in their 2023 CAP. She said the staff have improved
in their efforts and compliance with completion of service plans and supervision
contacts. She stated the social work contacts have consistently been addressed
monthly by pulling data from info view and assessing the requirements. She
stated this data along with the results are shared with MDHHS, and a narrative is
written about the overall progress for that month.
Financial Overview
The agency annual audit by an independent certified public accountant dated
September 2023 and 2022, and their annual budget were reviewed. No concerns
were noted.
Staff Interviews

Three staff were interviewed on-site. All three staff reported being with the agency
three or four years. All three staff stated they feel supported by their
coworkers/team and their supervisors. The staff states their supervisors are
always available and assist them greatly with solving issues in identified areas.
For improvement for the agency, one staff suggested the agency should involve all
program staff and implement a crisis plan utilizing all employees on a rotating
basis to prevent burn out when crisis situations occur. Another staff suggested
having a quarterly/semiannual motivational meeting along with food to boost the
staff moral and to show appreciation.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The building has adequate space to provide the required services for families and
their children. The office has secure storage for confidential information. There is
adequate space for staff and clients to conduct business and hold visitation.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
